ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Macroeconomics, Solow model, AS_AD model
This course provides a great buildup to more advanced econ courses.
macroeconomics
I learned a lot about macroeconomics.
I refined my macroeconomics knowledge and tools and expanded on what I learned in intro.
Macroeconomics and economic thinking
More in-depth macroeconomics than I learned in previous economics classes.
Macroeconomics, monetary policy, a better understanding of how the economy actually works.
Macroeconomic analysis and understanding the economy.

I developed a greater understanding of modern economic models and how they are derived from more basic economic principles. I learned not only how to derive these models, but also how to apply them in real world contexts to study phenomena such as income inequality, short run fluctuations, and long run GDP growth.
knowledge of interest rates, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, the job market, and economic models for macro events.
Furthered my knowledge of macroeconomics and the mathematical foundations of monetary policy.
Am intermediate knowledge of Macroeconomics

This course was divided into three major section.  We learned about long term economic growth through capital and productivity accumulation, labor market models, and short run fluctuations in the economy.

I learned about macroeconomic long-term growth models, labor markets and job search models, and short-term models of output fluctuations and inflation. I learned this using mathematical models and intuitions, historical examples, and current examples surrounding the covid pandemic. I gained a better insight as to how the fed decides to set interest rates, and how those interest rates affect other metrics like GDP. I also learned about technological progress and allocation of workers can affect a country's long-term growth.
I definitely learned about a wide range of macro topics and feel comfortable with most of the information.
Broad macroeconomic knowledge.
Greater knowledge of macroeconomics.
Basic understanding of macroeconomics - the rationale behind models, ways to look at empirical data, and more importantly, the combination applying these to real life cases such as the Covid crisis.

I learned how to pursue a subject I was not very comfortable with. I will say that I did not gain that many practical skills, and I think Intro Macro suffices for non-Econ majors, but the TAs were helpful here.
Fundamentals of macroeconomics, how economies function on a larger scale
I gained a greater understanding of macroeconomic theory, inequality, and practical applications of calculus.
I learnt how to build on the foundations of macroeconomics learnt in the intro class, and how to apply more calculus to these concepts.
Learned a lot about macroeconomics: solow long run model, competitive labor model, search frictions labor model, short run model.
I honestly learned a lot. Couldn't say what specifically though.
i learned macroeconomic concepts
Understanding of macroeconomics, as it pertains to monetary policy, fiscal policy, long term growth, inequality, and the multiple factors associated in determining economics policy.
I learned about how to quantify the ways in which the economy evolves overtime.
I learned more in depth analysis of macroeconomic topics.
I learned new and important macroeconomic concepts while adding mathematical intuition to those that I had already explored in the introductory class.
I learned quantitative models which helped me gain a deeper understanding into the fundamentals of macroeconomic theory

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: helpful TAs and psets, Weaknesses: no recordings of lectures and I don't understand what is being said bc of masks. Also why is the final 50% of our grade like that's so unnecessary.

Strengths: well-organized, prof and TAs were helpful. Learned some macro. Weaknesses: Not a very compelling course, dull material, sometimes very long psets. Would have liked it more if we learnt more real-world applications

professor super boring
course should be recorded
professor
The course was not recorded - which was difficult during the pandemic.
There isn't much to the course. I thought it was good that they brought in current events/COVID shock.
Well organized, good explanations, high workload at times

Lectures and other materials could have been better notated - ie, what are parameters in the model?
Otherwise, pretty thorough covering of topics
Great lectures. Relevant PSETS (not too bad, if you go to office hours). Overall, can't complain.
Strong professor, good TAs and helpful sections. Material was well-organized.

The sections for this course were incredibly helpful for understanding the math covered in the problem sets and exams; however, the sections covered the math for the previously due problem set, rather than the upcoming problem set. Since lectures move at such a quick pace and spend more time covering concepts and derivations than mathematical applications, it would have been much more beneficial to discuss the math relating to upcoming problem sets in sections.

Strengths: good peer tutors and team of TFs
Weaknesses: would prefer 2 midterms instead of 1 because there was a lot of pressure during each exam given those 2 assessments made up 80% of the grade.
This course could be taught more clearly

The strengths of this course is the clear division and theme of each unit.  The topics were grouped together intelligently and the transition into a new unit was clear.  The TF's were also very helpful in recapping material learned during lectures.  A weakness of the course is the inconsistency of the difficulty and styles of the problem sets.
could use more conceptual discussions beyond just the mathematics

A major strength was our TF, who always was able to present topics covered in class in a new, but clear and concise manner. Also, our professor always seemed engaged with students and encouraged us to come to him with any confusion we may have had. The biggest downside was the inconsistency between some of the psets; some were much more helpful with understanding the course material, while others seemed like hours of busy work.
The course could be improved with more discussion of current issues.
Sections could be more structured. I liked the pace of lectures.
Well organized and taught, but the final was heavily weighted (50% of grade).

Prof. Zilibotti gives amazing lectures! Hes so good at explaining things and so committed to helping students understand the coursework. The TAs and paper tutors have been extremely helpful too. I wont be able to understand everything without their section and office hours.

Strengths -  Great and efficient TAs. Professor really does care about the well-being of the students.
Weaknesses - The lectures could be organized better and maybe less material to cover throughout the sem.

Strengths: good lecture notes, decent pace
Weakness: lecture could be more engaging, topics could be explained better

The course was a bit unorganized. The files for the lectures on Canvas often didnt match what was taught in class or mislabeled. Whether or not the sections were optional was also a point of confusion for the first few weeks.

The sections were really helpful and I wish some more of the maths was covered in class. The slides were the majority of the material but it was a weakness that essentially lectures were the professor reading off them.

I found the course interesting and Professor Zilibotti to be an engaged professor who cared about his students. I think it would have been nice to have the option of in-person OH with him. But I understand if he felt uncomfortable because of covid.
Lectures seemed boring, but I did not really find the material interesting which is on me.
hard class

Strength: quantitative basis for macro topics 
Something to improve: more theoretical content

Strength - The professors and the TFs are very kind, making sure they do all that they can to ensure that the students understand the material, as well as providing accommodations so that the workload isn't overwhelming. 

Weaknesses - 
1. Sometimes the lecture slides that are posted on Canvas are a little different than the ones presented in class, which sometimes made it confusing in terms of note-taking. This became less of an issue later on throughout the course, so maintaining the status quo would be great.
2. I wish there were more explanations on the lecture slides - sometimes I'd be looking back at some slides and I wouldn't understand what was going on in the slide. It definitely is on me for not taking more detailed lecture notes, but it would help a lot.

The strengths were that the course was interesting and the topics were all relevant to our current world. A weakness was that some of the material that was quite difficult was covered very quickly, while some of the easier material had tons of time dedicated to it.
Lectures were useful but sometimes dwelled on one topic for too long.  Problem sets were a fair representation of the course material and exams were challenging but fair.

I thought this course was well organized. I appreciated how Prof. Zilibotti took time to connect topics in class to current day events. He also would occasionally do dynamic models which I found to be helpful in understanding certain topics, like the shift of AS-AD curves over several periods, for example.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: not if you don't require it for the major!
only if you need it for your major
No, unless required for the major.
Not unless you need to take it.
Not unless you need it for your major. I learned more economic intuition in my intro macro class than I did here. This was just more complicated models, didn't provide much added value for me.
its a hard class. Dont take with zilibotti, take with nordhaus
yes
Yes! If you are an econ major, it gives you a better understanding of economics.
Yes, because it is a requirement for the economics major. I wouldn't say it is a fun class to take if you're just interested in the subject.
Good course, well organized
Take if you are econ major
Take it with Zilibotti. He's great.
Yes, interesting content.
Yes if necessary for your major. Provides a good macro foundation.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in economics. The class is similar in structure to introductory economics courses, and can be enjoyable if you find interest in the topics covered. However, I would not recommend this class to someone who does not need it for their major. There are much easier QR and Social Science credits available.
If you don't have to take it as a requirement, I wouldn't recommend taking it.

I would generally only recommend this course for those who require it for their major.  The topics are generally not used beyond the scope of economics, so those considering this class outside this major should enjoy rigorous analysis of models with many moving parts.

I'd recommend this course and this professor to any other econ major that needs to fulfill their macro requirements. It may be a bit dry to learn for an elective course coming from another major as it is fairly theorhetical and math heavy. However, it seems to give good preparation for further studies in macroeconomics and development. For example, econ 122 with Fabrizio definitely helped me understand the papers, articles, and speeches I had to read for a class on the financial crisis of 2008.
Only if their choice was between this course and intermediate micro.
Only if it's a requirement. There are more interesting Econ courses.
Yes, if econ major or want to develop knowledge of macroeconomic theory.
Yes, and especially when ones choosing between micro or macro
Really not unless you have to take it.
Yes if they are interested in learning more about the fundamentals of economic theories
No, I would not recommend this course to anyone who does not need to take it.
If necessary for the major

I enjoyed this course but I'm not sure everyone would. I think if you have to take it it can be enjoyable, but don't take it if not. Unless you really like econ, like me (I'm not an econ major and just took it for fun).
Intermediate Micro is better if you are Global.
Yes, mainly because I believe it is in everybody's best interest to have some understanding of how the economics system in the US functions, at least on a theoretical basis.
Yes! It offers an excellent knowledge base for those interested in macro.
I would recommend it to people who have an interest in more advanced economic analysis without a focus on math.
If you are interested in economics or are considering the economics major, I recommend this course.  It is not a course to be taken for fun.
It's a requirement. I took this over Intermediate Micro because I heard it was less math-intensive, and that seemed to hold up.
